entry.title: Infoset Field Length Limit
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am working with InfoSets for the 1st time, and need some guidance. My requirement is to fetch particular fields from the QMEL table and include a text field which will fetch data from the READ_TEXT function module.

Creating a new InfoSet via SQ02, I have added the QMEL table as a field group and have declared a variable LONGTEXT of type char, specifying length of 999 (as the text from READ_TEXT is touching close to 800-900 characters) The variable can only be defined as a pre-defined type in the InfoSet, so STRING is out of the question as well (although I would appreciate if someone could tell me if and how it would be possible).

However, even after concatenating the lines from READ_TEXT into my LONGTEXT variable and exporting into a spreadsheet, the data is only being displayed till 255 characters. The rest is being truncated.

I thought of an approach to declare multiple variables and start populating each one till it reaches 255 characters, then split the text into the next variable, and so on. However, that will create multiple columns in the spreadsheet and is not being accepted by the reviewers.

I have attached the screenshots of my data declaration and custom code as well.

Is there any way that I can approach this requirement without going for a custom program?

Thanks in advance,

Amar

entry.title: Progressive OJT Confirmation with one or multiple Observers
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

  • In a regulated and validated environment where activities must be documented in real time, how do you manage OJT (On-the-Job Training) confirmation during operations?
  • Key constraints:
    • Training follows the operational schedule.
    • Availability of qualified observers and the trainee.
    • Completion of OJT tasks may span several days or even weeks.
  • With the current version of LMS:
    • There is an option to progressively save task completion, but the signature can only be applied once for all tasks at the end.
    • If another observer opens the OJT, they cannot see what has already been confirmed by the previous observer; they start from scratch.
  • Desired system behavior:
    • An OJT may require multiple observers.
    • Each observer can validate only the tasks they supervised.
    • The last observer can view the observations made by colleagues within the OJT and sign their part at the end.
  • Questions :
    1. How do you manage progressive OJT confirmation in this context?
    2. How do you handle situations where multiple observers are involved in the same OJT?
    3. Have you successfully implemented other improvements for managing OJT completion in your LMS?

Thank you in advance for your feedback and for sharing your experience!

entry.title: Re: US PAYROLL - /N Series Technical Wagetypes
entry.content:
Hello Vivekasri, 

The /N series wage types usually refer to scenarios involving insufficient funds. These wage types represent various deductions that could not be taken because the employee's net pay was not sufficient to cover them.

For instance, wage type /N01, according to the documentation, represents the withholding tax calculated by BSI but not taken due to insufficient funds.

You can find more detailed information about specific /N wage types by checking the V_512W_D view, which contains documentation for various wage types used in SAP HCM Payroll.

These wage types are generated during the payroll run when the system identifies that the employee's net pay is inadequate to cover certain deductions. This process ensures that payroll calculations are accurate and that any discrepancies are clearly documented.

If you have any specific questions please feel free to ask. 

Best regards, 
Ana Falc√£o
HCM NA Developer

entry.title: How To Select The Correct Print Queue Based on Work Center in Output Control
entry.content:
It is necessary to ensure that the Handling Unit (HU) label printout is sent to the appropriate printer, considering that multiple printers may be used for HU label printing. The printer selection should occur automatically based on predefined conditions.

How can the correct printer be identified so that the HU label is printed on the device located closest to the final work center of the production order?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How To Select The Correct Print Queue Based on Work C...
entry.content:
A suitable approach is to incorporate additional decision rules within Output Parameter Determination. To obtain the intended behavior, the following design can be used:

1. Capture the last work center on the HU or a related object:
A field is required on the Handling Unit (or on an associated item or packaging object) that stores the last work center in which the HU was processed. If such a field is not available in the standard structure, it may be necessary to create it through Key User Extensibility using the Custom Fields and Custom Logic applications. If the HU header does not contain this information, the determination logic cannot operate as expected.

2. Configure the Output Parameter Determination decision table:
In the Output Parameter Determination application (application: Handling Unit; determination step: Printer Settings), the work center‚Äîeither a standard field or a custom field‚Äîshould be added as a condition column.
Decision rules can then be maintained, for example:
‚Äì If Work Center = A ‚Üí Printer = Print_Queue_A
‚Äì If Work Center = B ‚Üí Printer = Print_Queue_B

Corresponding rules should be created for all relevant work centers, with these entries placed at the top of the decision table and set as exclusive to ensure that only the first matching rule is applied.

entry.title: Understanding Seamless Planning
entry.content:
Introduction to Seamless Planning  

Seamless Planning is a new integration paradigm between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and SAP Datasphere that unifies planning logic with enterprise-grade data storage and governance. It allows SAC to remain the planning experience and calculation engine while Datasphere becomes the authoritative and governed persistence layer for plan data and master data. This means planning teams can reuse planning data across analytics, data transformation pipelines, and operational applications‚Äîwithout duplicating or exporting data outside of SAC. Modelers can build SAC planning models that physically store their transactional data and public dimensions inside Datasphere. They also have control over whether planning artifacts from SAC are exposed in Datasphere for reuse across Spaces or downstream analytic models.

Technical Architecture

  • Model Metadata & Planning Logic: Planning calculations, version management, and data actions remain defined inside SAC.
  • Fact Data & Dimensions Stored in Datasphere: The planning model‚Äôs fact tables and public dimensions are persisted in Datasphere to enable governed reuse and enterprise distribution.
  • Data Exposure from SAC to Datasphere: SAC can expose selected planning objects as read-only Datasphere artifacts, enabling modelers to use these objects in Data Builder or transform them into Analytical Models.

Key Benefits

  • Unified Planning Data: Centralized storage of plan facts and dimensions in Datasphere ensures consistency across systems and workflows.
  • Direct Persistence to Datasphere: Changes made in SAC planning flows are instantly reflected in Datasphere fact tables‚Äîno manual exports required.
  • Optimized SAC Resource Usage: Offloading data storage to Datasphere reduces SAC‚Äôs memory and storage footprint.
  • Enterprise Reusability & Governance: Datasphere‚Äôs modeling and transformation extend to planning data, enabling secure and scalable reuse in the form of analytic models.

This approach eliminates data silos, reduces duplication, and empowers organizations to operationalize planning data across their digital landscape‚Äîwhile preserving SAC‚Äôs rich planning experience at the front end.

Prerequisites for Seamless Planning

Before configuring or deploying planning models from SAC to Datasphere, ensure the following system prerequisites are met.

  1. SAC Tenant Must Be Running on SAP HANA Cloud
    • SAC must be provisioned on SAP HANA Cloud infrastructure.
    • To verify: Navigate to System ‚Üí About in SAC and confirm the HANA Cloud version is listed.
    • This ensures compatibility with Datasphere‚Äôs storage and modeling architecture.

 2.  Tenant Co-Location and 1:1 Linkage

  • Both SAC and Datasphere tenants must reside in the same SAP data center region.
  • A 1:1 tenant relationship is required‚Äîeach SAC tenant must be linked to a single Datasphere tenant.
  • This linkage enables SAC to persist planning data directly into Datasphere spaces.
  • This can be done in System √† Administration √† Tenant Links in both SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Datasphere.

3. Consistent Identity Provider (IdP) Configuration

  • It is strongly recommended that both tenants use the same SAML-based Identity Provider (IdP).
  • This ensures consistent user identity mapping across SAC and Datasphere.

4. System Owner Credentials on Both Tenants

  • The tenant linkage process requires authentication using a system owner account on both SAC and Datasphere.
  • This account must have administrative privileges to authorize cross-tenant integration.

5. User Role Assignment in Datasphere Space

    • SAC users who need to create, edit, or expose planning models must be granted appropriate space-level roles in Datasphere.
    • Without these roles, SAC will not be able to write data or expose model objects to the designated Datasphere space.

If any of the above conditions are not met, then Datasphere will not appear as a selectable data storage location in SAC. The  SAP Knowledge Base Article 3515100 highlights certain errors along with their corresponding workarounds.

Workflow for Seamless Planning

  1. Create a New Model in SAC: While creating a new Model in SAC, there is an option available to specify the Data Storage Location as a Space within SAP Datasphere.

2. Configure Dimensions and Measures:  The model created with Datasphere persistence layer is created as a Planning Measure based model by default and the data storage location is Datasphere Space as shown in model details.

3. Expose to Datasphere: There is also an additional option in the Model Details to expose the underlying fact table in the chosen Datasphere space. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

4. What gets created in Datasphere: When a SAC planning model is configured to store data in Datasphere:

  • A Fact object (read-only) becomes visible in the Datasphere Space.
  • A corresponding physical table (sap.sac.<GUID>) is created to store transactional planning data.
  • Any public dimensions used in the model are created in Datasphere as dimension tables and remain shareable across Space.

5. Execute Planning scenarios in SAC: With the new model now exposed in Datasphere, key planning scenarios can continue to be executed within SAC exactly as before. Seamless Planning does not alter the way SAC planning processes run; it simply extends the option to persist and integrate data through Datasphere while maintaining the familiar SAC planning experience.

  • Create and Execute a Data Action: Develop a Data Action in SAC to update planning data. Once executed, publish the updated data back to Datasphere to ensure synchronization across platforms.
  • Conduct Actual vs Plan Analysis: Utilize SAC's analytical capabilities to compare actual performance against planned figures. This enables variance analysis and supports informed decision-making.
  • Extend Modelling in Datasphere: Build custom calculations directly within SAP Datasphere using the exposed model. Create a dedicated view and Analytical Model on top of these calculations, then visualize the results seamlessly in SAC for enhanced planning insights.

Important Considerations

SAP is actively working to reduce the space dependency in future releases, for latest updates please refer the SAP Roadmap Explorer and the help guide.

  • Cross-Model Planning Constraints: Currently all models involved in cross-model planning operations‚Äîsuch as a data action, cross-model copy step must be in the same Datasphere space.
  • Shared Public Dimensions:  Sharing public dimensions across multiple models is only supported when both the models and the associated public dimensions are deployed within the same SAP Datasphere space. The same requirement applies to currency rate tables, which must reside in the same space to be referenced across models.
  • Hierarchies:  Hierarchies defined in SAP Analytics Cloud are not exposed to SAP Datasphere. If hierarchical structures are required for modeling or reporting, Datasphere modelers must reconstruct these hierarchies natively within Datasphere, ensuring alignment with the underlying data model and semantic layer.

Seamless Planning in BDC

SAP is introducing a unified enterprise planning paradigm through SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). This represents the next stage in the evolution of Seamless Planning, where planning activities are connected, real-time, and driven by trusted operational data‚Äîeliminating the traditional ‚Äúexport, transform, and import‚Äù workflow. Because SAC and Datasphere are core components of BDC, seamless planning is highly relevant in this context and establishes the foundation for deep integration of planning data within the BDC environment. Looking ahead, BDC has the potential to further enrich seamless planning by:

  • Supporting planning-enabled intelligent applications that combine analytics with actionable planning workflows.
  • Extending planning architectures to include platforms such as SAP Databricks.
  • Enabling the consumption of data products directly within planning processes, ensuring governed, reusable, and scalable planning assets.

To understand Seamless Planning in context of Business Data Cloud, please refer to this blog.

entry.title: Re: Error Message: Error in File ~tmp3e00d40bd1a7740.rpt:...
entry.content:
Due to the nature of dll's they are not capable of returning the actual error from deep down, it's only the top layer that can report the error. As Ido is suggesting it's likely due to either too much data or the Server is too busy to manage all of the DB connections. Each report and subreports per main report filtering will make a separate connection to the DB. For example if the main report returns 100 results for the subreport there will be 100 connection to the dB server. Remember CR is a Reporting tool, it's not a database archiving tool....

Another option is to add more filtering server side using Stored Procedures so not so much data is being returned and expecting CR to do the filtering client side....

entry.title: Re: Actual Cost Accounting and Moving Average Cost
entry.content: Good morning , i think i understood your question . if the product is using standard price , this standard price will never change unless you do the cost estimate for it (CK40N/CK11N) . for example there is a raw material A , a raw material B , and a finished product C . BOM of finished product C is : C(1pc) = A(1pc) + B(1pc) . C and A is using standard price , B is using moving average price . after the first cost estimate for C and A , the standard price of them is : C = 100 JPY/pc , A = 80 JPY/pc , this time the moving average price of B is 20 JPY/pc . then later , moving average price of B will change when you do the goods receipt with different price , but A and C will not change because no cost estimate(CK40N/CK11N) happened . after 1 month , standard price of A and C is not changed , moving average price of B become 30 JPY/pc . if you do the cost estimate (CK40N/CK11N) for C again , then the standard price of C will become 110 JPY/pc = 80 JPY/pc (A) + 30 JPY/pc (B) .

entry.title: Re: Is There a Way to Add Conditional Formula for Text In...
entry.content:
There is, what you need to do is the Clone() method to copy the property bag of the object and use Old/New to apply the changes

For more info on using Clone() and the below example see this sample app, it's C# but the same functions for VB:

how-to-parameters-in-crystal-reports-for-visual-studio-net

Look in the drop down box on the right and "Object Name -> Field Name"

Here's how to get the info: C# but the same for VB.

CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ReportObjects rptObjs;
//rptObjs = rptClientDoc.ReportDefController.ReportObjectController.GetReportObjectsByKind(CrReportObjectKindEnum.crReportObjectKindField);
rptObjs = rptClientDoc.ReportDefController.ReportObjectController.GetAllReportObjects();

foreach (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ReportObject rptObj1 in rptObjs)
{
    switch (rptObj1.Kind)
    {
        case CrReportObjectKindEnum.crReportObjectKindField:
            CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.FieldObject fldObj1;
            fldObj1 = (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.FieldObject)rptObj1;

            //CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum

            btnReportObjects.Text += "Name: " + fldObj1.Name.ToString();
            btnReportObjects.Text += "\n Kind: " + rptObj1.Kind.ToString() + "-> " + fldObj1.DataSourceName.ToString();

            if (fldObj1.FieldFormat.StringFormat.TextFormat == CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum.crTextFormatRTFText)
                btnReportObjects.Text += "\n RTF: = true";
            if (fldObj1.FieldFormat.StringFormat.TextFormat == CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum.crTextFormatHTMLText)
                btnReportObjects.Text += "\n HTML: = true";
            if (fldObj1.FieldFormat.StringFormat.TextFormat == CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum.crTextFormatStandardText)
                btnReportObjects.Text += "\n Standard Text: = true";

To use Clone() check out the API Ref Guide

C_S4PM2_2507, which is a more pure-bred PM/PgM-oriented.

SAP appears to favour (please correct if wrong) the first, entry level certification, rather than the associate ('C') certification. This is the information I got, and I personally doubt it, hence my reliance on your feedback.

Questions:

Is the 'E_xxx' examination still warranted under the current withdrawal / retired learning curriculum?

Is indeed the 'E_xxx' examination considered by SAP as a priority instead of the associate 'C_xxx' examination?

Thanks a lot.

Paul

Can I assign these two company codes to one Controlling Area?

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to include values from multiple models...
entry.content:
@tsuuu You are very close you have done most of the steps correctly. But I think the issue comes from adding a new dimension to an existing model.

When you add a new dimension, SAC does not know which value to use for the existing data rows. That is why it asks you to choose a default member. Since you selected ‚Äú#‚Äù (unassigned), SAC has now assigned ‚Äú#‚Äù to all the existing rows in your model for that new dimension.

Because of this, when you go to the story and try to filter by company code, the filter does not work as expected the data is actually stored with ‚Äú#‚Äù, not with TEST or any other company code.

There is a simple way to fix this. Since your model is small and only has test data, I suggest this approach (DO NOT DO THIS IF ACTUAL DATA IS INVOLVED):

  1. Add the public Company Code dimension to your model.

  2. Delete the existing data in the model.

  3. Reload your data again.

When you load the data after adding the dimension, you can map the company code from your source data to this public dimension correctly.

This should make your input control work as expected.

entry.title: Scrapping Materials from Warehouse
entry.content:
Hi Experts,
I am seeking your advice on how to address a current business requirement related to our scrapping process.
At present, the warehouse receives a long list of valuated materials from Finance that need to be scrapped. The warehouse posts the scrapping using MIGO with movement type 551. After the MIGO posting is completed, the system generates a Transfer Requirement (TR) and subsequently a Transfer Order (TO), which allows pickers to use the RF gun for picking.
However, the warehouse‚Äôs concern is that this process does not include a release strategy, unlike what is available in the Purchase Order process. Because of this, the business is considering two alternative approaches:

Option 1: Sales Order (VA01) with a New Order Type for Scrapping

  1. Would require setting up a generic Sold-to Party and Ship-to Party specifically for scrapping.
  2. Proper G/L account and cost center assignment would be required to ensure correct financial posting.
  3. Limitation: This method does not support a release strategy, which is a key control requirement.

Option 2: Internal Purchase Order for Scrapping

  1. A Purchase Order can incorporate a Release Strategy, which addresses the control concern.
  2. However, questions arise regarding the supplier setup:
  3. Would this require creating an internal vendor?
  4. Would this effectively become a type of STO process, and how would the end-to-end flow work?
  5. Additional consideration is ensuring correct posting to the appropriate G/L accounts and cost centers.

I would appreciate your guidance or recommended approach to meet the following objectives:

  1. Ensure scrapping has an appropriate approval / release mechanism.
  2. Maintain an efficient warehouse execution process, including TR/TO creation and RF picking.
  3. Avoid unnecessary complexity or unintended financial impacts.

Any insights, best practices, or step-by-step guidance would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: Actual Cost Accounting and Moving Average Cost
entry.content:
Hello @makoto_kasuya91 ,

-Yes ‚Äî SAP‚Äôs Actual Costing (Material Ledger Actual Costing) applies only to materials with Standard Price control (S).
-Materials with Moving Average Price (V) do not participate in actual costing; they are valued only at moving average, based on actual goods movements.
-When materials with mixed price controls (standard + MAP) interact (e.g., consumption, subcontracting, multi-level BOMs), SAP calculates:
*Actual cost rollup for standard-priced materials only
*MAP materials consume or issue at the current moving average, without revaluation during actual costing

Example:-

 

ItemMaterial A (FG)Material B (Component)Material C (Component)
Price ControlS (Standard)S (Standard)V (Moving Average)
Price Before Posting100 USD (Std Price)40 USD (Std Price)20 USD MAP
Consumption Qty for 1 FG‚Äî1 pc1 pc
Consumption Valuation at Posting‚Äî40 USD20 USD (MAP at that moment)
Actual Events During PeriodProduced 1 FGInvoice price difference: GR 40 ‚Üí IR 45 (Variance +5)Multiple GRs at different prices ‚Üí MAP auto-updated (20 ‚Üí 25 ‚Üí 21.67)
How SAP Treats Differences During MonthNo valuation changePrice variance collected in MLMAP automatically recalculated after each GR; no variance collected
Participation in Actual Costing (ML Period-End Closing)YesYesNo
What Happens at Actual Costing Closing?Receives rolled-up variances from componentsVariance +5 USD is rolled up to FGNo revaluation; MAP remains final MAP (21.67)
Adjustment Posted at Period-End+5 USD added to actual FG costVariance settled to FG0 USD (no settlement)
Final Actual Cost ImpactActual Cost = 105 USDVariance transferredMAP consumed but not revalued

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to restrict multiple parkings of supplier invoices
entry.content:
Problem Background:

A customer has requested a requirement to restrict the repeated parking of goods receipt reference documents and reference document items corresponding to purchase orders that have already been parked and posted. If a purchase order has already completed goods receipt, reference document, and invoice posting, it should no longer be possible to park an invoice for this purchase order.

Solution:

Attempt to meet the requirement through custom logic using a BAdI.

Analysis Steps:

1. We have previously assisted customers with invoicing requirements, and the business enhancement points we need to use are the same. You can refer to these two blogs: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to check if the payment terms of pre made invoices are consistent with those in supplier master data | SAP Blogs and Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to restrict invoicing of purchase orders with incomplete receipts | SAP Blogs .

First, we need to add an enhancement implementation in the application - Custom Logic of SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. According to the business scenario, select the business context Procurement: Supplier Invoice and business add-in description Check Invoice Data, and fill in the implementation description and implementation identifier.

2. After adding the enhancement implementation in Custom Logic, we need to find the CDS Views that can provide the business requirement fields. After testing, for the same PO + ITEM + goods receipt, if it has already been posted, the same goods receipt document cannot be selected again for repeated parking. Therefore, the fields I use as validation conditions here are PO and ITEM numbers. At the same time, since we need to check whether this PO and ITEM have already been posted, we need to use SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5' in I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01. However, this CDS View does not have the PO and ITEM fields, so we need to use I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01. In the sample code below, I used a custom CDS View. You can create a custom CDS View YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 in your own system based on I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01, select the corresponding fields, and make adjustments.

At the same time, as I mentioned in my previous articles, in the sample code provided by the BAdI, we can find statements that can restrict the behavior that triggers the BAdI. According to our needs, we need to add the following statement to restrict the BAdI to only trigger during invoice parking, without affecting other processes:

Park: if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Park

3. Based on the above analysis, implement the BAdI. The specific code is as follows.

loop at ITEMSWITHPOREFERENCE REFERENCE INTO DATA(Supinvoice_item).
if action = if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Hold.
    select single 
    from YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 with privileged access
    where PURCHASEORDER = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDER and PURCHASEORDERITEM = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDERITEM
    and SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5'
    into (Is_Supinvoice_status) .
    if Is_Supinvoice_status = abap_true.
      append value #( messagetype = 'E' messageid = 'MRM_BADI_CLOUD' messagenumber = '001' messagevariable1 = 'ÊöÇÂ≠òÁöÑÂèëÁ•®ÊúâÈáçÂ§çÈ°πÁõÆ„ÄÇ' ) to messages.
    endif.
endif.
endloop.

Conclusion:

By reading this article and several previous blogs on similar scenarios, I hope you now understand how to use custom logic to apply certain restrictions when creating preliminary invoices for purchase orders.
You can find more information about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement-related issues at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

You can also read more blogs about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

If you have any suggestions or thoughts about this article, please feel free to share them in the comments section. I look forward to communicating with you. You are also welcome to follow my personal account, and I look forward to seeing you in the next blog post!

entry.title: Event Driven Integration Using SAP Integration Suite, Solace, HANA DB, and OpenAI Validation
entry.content:
1. Introduction

This prototype implements an event driven pattern using SAP Integration Suite and Solace. A JSON event is published to Solace and processed by an iFlow that applies AI based validation, routes the result, updates a HANA Cloud table, and records a structured log entry. The objective is to demonstrate event reception, AI assisted validation, routing logic, data extraction, and persistence on SAP BTP.

2. Overview

This prototype uses Solace as the event broker and SAP Integration Suite as the consumer and processing layer. A JSON event is published to a Solace topic, and SAP Integration Suite subscribes to this topic to receive each message. Once the event is received, the iFlow generates a trace identifier, captures the original JSON payload, applies an AI based validation step, and routes the message based on the validation result.

Two HANA Cloud tables support the processing. One table stores the final validated record. The second table stores the audit entry containing the original JSON, processing status, trace identifier, and error information.

Two iFlows are used in this prototype.

  • One iFlow publishes a JSON event to Solace.
  • One iFlow consumes the event, validates it, routes it, and updates the HANA tables.

The end to end processing sequence is as follows.

  • A JSON event is published to Solace
  • SAP Integration Suite receives the event from the subscribed topic
  • A trace identifier is generated and the payload is captured
  • OpenAI validates the payload
  • Valid messages update the CITIZEN_MASTER table
  • All messages are written to NIXP_LOG

3 Demo

4. Design Flow

Integration Flow design contains the following components.

4.1 CitizenCreated_Publisher
 
4.1.1 Implementation Details for Publisher iFlow
 
 
4.2 CitizenCreated_Consumer
 
 
4.2.1 Implementation Details for Consumer iFlow

4.2.1.1 GenerateTraceId Groovy

Creates a unique identifier that is stored as a property and used in all logs and database operations.

String traceId = UUID.randomUUID().toString();

 

4.2.1.2 CaptureOriginalPayload Groovy

Reads the incoming payload as a complete text string and stores it in ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD. This prevents streaming issues and ensures the original JSON is always available for validation, UPSERT, and logging.

message.setProperty("ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD", bodyAsString)

 

4.2.1.3 AIQualityCheck

Constructs the OpenAI request by embedding the citizen JSON and instructing the model to return a structured validation result with fields valid and reason.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Read the original JSON as string
    String bodyString = ""
    try {
        bodyString = message.getBody(String)
    } catch (Exception e) {
        bodyString = ""
    }
    // explicit validation rules 
    String systemPrompt = """
You are a data quality validator for NIXP citizen registration events.
You must validate ONLY the following rules on the JSON payload:
1) citizenId must be present and a positive integer (e.g. 1, 2, 100).
2) firstName must be present, non-empty, and primarily alphabetic characters (letters, spaces, simple punctuation allowed).
3) lastName must be present, non-empty, and primarily alphabetic characters.
Other fields (for example dateOfBirth, address, extra, etc.) MAY be present or absent and MUST NOT influence validity.
You MUST NOT require any additional fields beyond citizenId, firstName, and lastName.
If the payload satisfies all three rules, set:
  valid = true
  reason = short explanation such as "All required fields are present and correctly formatted."
If any rule fails, set:
  valid = false
  reason = short explanation listing which rule(s) failed.
You must return ONLY a JSON object with exactly two keys:
  valid   (boolean)
  reason  (string)
""".stripIndent()
    // message with the actual payload
    String userContent = "Payload: " + bodyString
    // Build the OpenAI chat completion request
    def requestJson = [
        model: "gpt-4.1-mini",
        response_format: [ type: "json_object" ],
        messages: [
            [
                role   : "system",
                content: systemPrompt
            ],
            [
                role   : "user",
                content: userContent
            ]
        ]
    ]
    String jsonBody = JsonOutput.toJson(requestJson)
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
    return message
}

4.2.1.4 BuildChatGPTReqheader Add message header Authorication and Content-type.

4.2.1.5 Request Reply  HTTP = Address: https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions; Method = Post

4.2.1.6 AIQualityResultParser

Parses the JSON response from OpenAI and extracts two fields ‚Äúvalid‚Äù and ‚Äúreason‚Äù. These values are stored in AI_VALID and AI_REASON and determine the next routing step.

4.2.1.7 Router

The router evaluates AI_VALID. If AI_VALID is true the message continues to the UPSERT path. If AI_VALID is false the message moves to the controlled error path. 

Valid path

ExtractCitizenProps reads ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD and extracts the values citizenId, firstName, and lastName.

4.2.1.8 SQLCreator

Exchange Property: Name = Query; Type = Expression; Value = UPSERT CITIZEN_MASTER ( CITIZEN_ID, FIRST_NAME, LAST_NAME, REGISTRATION_TIMESTAMP, REGISTRATION_CHANNEL, REGISTRATION_STATUS ) VALUES ( ${property.CITIZEN_ID}, '${property.FIRST_NAME}', '${property.LAST_NAME}', CURRENT_UTCTIMESTAMP, '${property.REG_CHANNEL}', '${property.REG_STATUS}' ) WITH PRIMARY KEY;

Message Body: Type = Expression; Body is ${property.Query}

4.2.1.9 Request Reply

A JDBC UPSERT updates CITIZEN_MASTER. A row with status Processed is written to NIXP_LOG.

Invalid path

4.2.1.10 RaiseAIValidationError Sets status Error and writes AI_REASON to ERROR_MESSAGE.

A row with status Error is written to NIXP_LOG using SQLCreatorLog (same settings as SQLCreator) Query is INSERT INTO NIXP_LOG ( CITIZEN_ID, RAW_JSON, STATUS, ERROR_MESSAGE, IFLOW_NAME, TRACE_ID, SOLACE_MESSAGE_ID ) VALUES ( ${property.CITIZEN_ID}, '${property.ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD}', '${property.STATUS}', '${property.ERROR_MESSAGE}', '${property.IFLOW_NAME}', '${property.TRACE_ID}', '${property.SOLACE_MESSAGE_ID}' );

4.2.1.11 Exception Subprocess will trigger in case of exception and uses log table to save the error information.

5 JBDC Matiral

6 Solace Setup

Solace credentials are created in ‚ÄúManage Security Material‚Äù.

Create Queue
Messaging ‚Üí Queues ‚Üí Create Queue

Queue name
NIXP.CITIZEN.CREATED.Q

Add Topic Subscription to Queue
Open the queue
Topic Subscriptions ‚Üí Add

Topic
nixp/citizen/created

This makes the queue receive all events published on that topic.

Create REST Delivery Point (RDP)
Messaging ‚Üí Client -> REST

Add REST Delivery Points

Name: NIXP_RDP


Add REST Consumer
Inside NIXP_RDP ‚Üí REST Consumers ‚Üí Add

Name: NIXP_REST_CONS
Remote Host:
consumer iflow endpoint‚Ä¶.rt.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com
Port: 443
Method: POST
Remote Path: /http/nixp/citizen/event
TLS: Enabled

Authentication: HTTP Basic
Username: CPI client id
Password: CPI client secret

Bind Queue to RDP
NIXP_RDP ‚Üí Queue Bindings ‚Üí Add

Queue: NIXP.CITIZEN.CREATED.Q
Post Request Target: /http/nixp/citizen/event
Add header: Content-Type : application/json

The Solace sender adapter is configured with a subscription to the NIXP topic. All events from this topic flow directly into SAP Integration Suite.

7 OpenAI model

The validation layer uses OpenAI chat completions with model gpt 4 point 1 mini. The request contains the citizen JSON and a prompt that instructs the model to return a structured JSON response with two fields ‚Äúvalid‚Äù and ‚Äúreason‚Äù. The response is processed by AIQualityResultParser which extracts AI_VALID and AI_REASON. These are simple boolean and string values that determine routing.

Postman Test:

{
    "model": "gpt-4.1-mini",
    "response_format": {
        "type": "json_object"
    },
    "messages": [
        {
            "role": "system",
            "content": "You are a data quality validator for citizen registration events. Given a JSON payload you must decide if it is valid for processing. Return only JSON containing keys valid and reason."
        },
        {
            "role": "user",
            "content": "Payload: {\r\n \"citizenId\": null,\r\n \"firstName\": \"12345\",\r\n \"lastName\": \"\",\r\n \"extra\": \"junk data\"\r\n}\r\n"
        }
    ]
}

Output:

{
    "id": "chatcmpl-Cdn9NmTxljW2LKBsYGyArWMUXd779",
    "object": "chat.completion",
    "created": 1763599761,
    "model": "gpt-4.1-mini-2025-04-14",
    "choices": [
        {
            "index": 0,
            "message": {
                "role": "assistant",
                "content": "{\n  \"valid\": false,\n  \"reason\": \"citizenId is null, lastName is empty, firstName contains numeric characters, extra field is not allowed\"\n}",
                "refusal": null,
                "annotations": []
            },
            "logprobs": null,
            "finish_reason": "stop"
        }
    ],
    "usage": {

entry.title: È©æÈ©≠Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÔºàAgentic AIÔºâÊó∂‰ª£ÔºöSAP ÁöÑAIÊ†∏ÂøÉÁ≠ñÁï•‰∏éÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÁöÑÊñ∞ËßíËâ≤
entry.content:
‰ªäÂπ¥ÁöÑ SAP TechEd Â§ß‰ºöÊ∏ÖÊô∞Âú∞Â±ïÁ§∫‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÊù°ÊäÄÊúØÊºîËøõË∑ØÂæÑÔºö‰ªé‰º†ÁªüÁöÑÊú¨Âú∞ÈÉ®ÁΩ≤Ôºàon premiseÔºâÔºåÂà∞‰∫ëÂéüÁîüÊû∂ÊûÑÔºàcloudÔºâÔºåÂÜçÂà∞Â¶Ç‰ªäÁöÑ AI È©±Âä®Êû∂ÊûÑÔºàAI-driven architectureÔºâ„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨Ê≠£Â§ÑÂú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁöÑÊû∂ÊûÑËΩ¨ÂûãÊúüÔºöAI Ê≠£‰ªé‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂçïÁ∫ØÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÊºîÂèò‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÄºÂæó‰ø°ËµñÁöÑÈòüÂèãÔºåËÉΩÂ§ü‰ΩúÂá∫ÂèØÈù†ÁöÑËá™‰∏ªÂÜ≥Á≠ñ„ÄÇ

Âú®Ëøô‰∏™ Agentic AI Êó∂‰ª£ÔºåÊäÄÊúØÊû∂ÊûÑÊ≠£Âú®ÈáçÂ°ëÔºåËÄå SAP Joule Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÔºàJoule AgentsÔºâÊ≠£ÊòØÂÆûÁé∞Ëøô‰∏ÄÂèòÈù©ÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÊîØÊü±„ÄÇ

Êú¨ÊñáÂ∞ÜÊ∑±ÂÖ•Êé¢ËÆ® Joule Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÊäÄÊúØÂü∫Á°Ä„ÄÅ‰ºÅ‰∏öÊû∂ÊûÑÂÆö‰Ωç‰ª•ÂèäÊú™Êù•ÂèëÂ±ïÂâçÊôØ„ÄÇÈòÖËØªÂ§ßÊ¶ÇÈúÄË¶Å5ÂàÜÈíüÊó∂Èó¥„ÄÇ

 

Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÂÆö‰Ωç‰∏é‰ΩìÁ≥ªÁªìÊûÑ

Joule Agents‚Äã ÁöÑÁõÆÊ†áÊòØÈ©±Âä®Á´ØÂà∞Á´ØÊµÅÁ®ãËá™Âä®ÂåñÔºåÂÆûÁé∞‚Äú‰ªéÂßãËá≥ÁªàÂÆåÊàêÂ∑•‰Ωú‚Äù„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰ª¨Ë¢´ËßÜ‰∏∫ SAP Suite-first‚Äã Âíå AI-first‚Äã ÊàòÁï•ÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÔºåÊó®Âú®Âä†ÈÄü‰ºÅ‰∏öÁöÑËΩ¨Âûã„ÄÇ

Âú® SAP ÁöÑÊô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì‰ΩìÁ≥ª‰∏≠Ôºå SAPÊûÑÂª∫‰∫ÜÊ∏ÖÊô∞ÁöÑ‰∏âÂ±ÇÁªìÊûÑÔºå‰ª•Á°Æ‰øùÁî®Êà∑‰ΩìÈ™åÁöÑÁÆÄÂåñÂíåÂêéÁ´ØÁöÑÂ§çÊùÇÊÄßÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÇJouleÊòØÁªü‰∏ÄÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°AI‰∫§‰∫íÁïåÈù¢, ÂÆ¢Êà∑‰∏é AI Âä©Êâã(AI Assistance)‰∫íÂä®,  AIÂä©ÊâãÂàôÁºñÊéíÊô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÂçèÂêåÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºåÊâìÁ†¥‰∏öÂä°Â≠§Â≤õÔºåËá™Âä®ÂåñË∑®ËÅåËÉΩÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅ„ÄÇ

  1. JouleÔºà‰ΩìÈ™åÂ±ÇÔºâÔºöÂÆÉÊòØ SAP Áªü‰∏ÄÁöÑ‰∏öÂä° AI Áî®Êà∑‰ΩìÈ™åÁïåÈù¢ÔºåÊòØÊâÄÊúâ AI Êô∫ËÉΩÁöÑÂçï‰∏ÄÂâçÁ´Ø„ÄÇ
  2. AI Âä©ÊâãÔºàÂä©ÊâãÂ±ÇÔºâÔºöËøô‰∫õÊòØÂü∫‰∫éËßíËâ≤ÁöÑ AI ÈòüÂèãÔºàpersona-based AI teammatesÔºâÔºåÈÄöËøá Joule ËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰ª¨Âõ¥ÁªïÂÆûÈôÖÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤ÔºàÂ¶ÇÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥¶Ê¨æÁªèÁêÜ„ÄÅÊãõËÅò‰∫∫ÂëòÔºâËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÊòØÁî®Êà∑‰ª•Ëá™ÁÑ∂ËØ≠Ë®ÄËøõË°å‰∫§‰∫íÁöÑËôöÊãüÂêå‰∫ã„ÄÇ
  3. Joule Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÔºàÊâßË°åÂ±ÇÔºâÔºöÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÊòØ‰∏ì‰∏öÂåñÁöÑÊûÑÂª∫ÂùóÔºàspecialized building blocksÔºâÔºåË¥üË¥£Âú®ÂêéÂè∞ËßÑÂàí„ÄÅÊé®ÁêÜÂπ∂ÊâßË°åÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑÂ§öÊ≠•È™§Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅ„ÄÇ

 

Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊú∫Âà∂‰∏éÊäÄÊúØÂü∫Á°Ä

Joule Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÂú®‰ºÅ‰∏öÁ∫ßÁéØÂ¢É‰∏≠ÂèØÈù†ËøêË°åÔºåÂæóÁõä‰∫éÂÖ∂Ê∑±Â∫¶ÈõÜÊàêÁöÑÊû∂ÊûÑÂíåÂ§öÈ°πÊ†∏ÂøÉÊäÄÊúØ„ÄÇ

SAP Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÊ†∏ÂøÉÁ´û‰∫âÂäõÊ∫ê‰∫éÂÖ∂Ê∑±ÂéöÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñáÔºàBusiness ContextÔºâÁêÜËß£ËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇÂÄüÂä©Ë¶ÜÁõñË¥¢Âä°„ÄÅ‰æõÂ∫îÈìæ„ÄÅ‰∫∫ÂäõËµÑÊ∫êÂíåÂÆ¢Êà∑‰ΩìÈ™åÁöÑ SAP Business SuiteÔºåAI ËÉΩÂ§üËøõË°åË∑®‰∏öÂä°ËåÉÂõ¥ÁöÑÊé®ÁêÜÔºåËÄåÈùûÂ±ÄÈôê‰∫éÂçï‰∏ÄÁ≥ªÁªü„ÄÇËøôÁßçËÉΩÂäõÂª∫Á´ãÂú®Áªü‰∏Ä„ÄÅÁÆ°ÁêÜÂíåÊ≤ªÁêÜÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂ±Ç‰πã‰∏äÔºåÂπ∂Áî± SAP Áü•ËØÜÂõæË∞±ÔºàSAP Knowledge GraphÔºâÊèê‰æõÊîØÊåÅ.

Ê∑±Â∫¶‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá‰∏éÁü•ËØÜÂõæË∞±ËµãËÉΩ:  

SAP Áü•ËØÜÂõæË∞±ÈÄöËøáËµãËÉΩÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÊé®ÁêÜËÉΩÂäõÊù•ÊèêÂçáÂÖ∂ÊïàÁéáÂíåÂáÜÁ°ÆÊÄß„ÄÇÂÆÉÊï¥Âêà‰∫Ü SAP 50 Â§öÂπ¥ÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã‰∏ì‰∏öÁü•ËØÜÔºåÂπ∂Êèê‰æõÂÖ≥‰∫éÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÅÊï∞ÊçÆ‰ª•ÂèäÂÖ∂ÂÖ≥Á≥ªÁöÑÊ∑±Â±Ç‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá„ÄÇÂú®Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑËøêË°åÊó∂ÔºåÊØè‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÈÉΩ‰ΩøÁî®Áü•ËØÜÂõæË∞±‰ª•Á°Æ‰øù‰∏öÂä°Âü∫Á°ÄÁöÑÂáÜÁ°ÆÊÄß„ÄÇÈÄöËøáÂ∞ÜÁü•ËØÜÂíåÊï∞ÊçÆËûçÂÖ•Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºåÂ¢ûÂº∫‰∫Ü‰ªªÂä°ÁªìÊûúÁöÑÂáÜÁ°ÆÊÄßÂíåÂèØÈù†ÊÄß„ÄÇ

Êï∞ÊçÆËÆøÈóÆ‰∏éÁªü‰∏ÄËØ≠‰πâÂ±Ç:  

Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÈÄöËøá SAP ‰∏öÂä°Êï∞ÊçÆ‰∫ëÔºàBusiness Data CloudÔºåBDCÔºâÂÆûÁé∞ÂØπÂÖ®Èù¢‰∏îÂÆâÂÖ®Êï∞ÊçÆÁöÑËÆøÈóÆÔºå‰ªéËÄåÊâìÁ†¥‰∫ÜÊï∞ÊçÆÂ≠§Â≤õ„ÄÇBDC ‰Ωú‰∏∫Âçï‰∏ÄÂèØ‰ø°ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂ±ÇÔºåÁ°Æ‰øùÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìËÉΩÂ§üÁ®≥ÂÆöÂú∞ËÆøÈóÆ‰ºÅ‰∏öÂÜÖÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Êï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇÈÄöËøáËØ≠‰πâÂØπÈΩêÔºåÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìËÉΩÂ§üÁªü‰∏ÄÂú∞Â§ÑÁêÜÊù•Ëá™ SAP ÂíåÈùû SAP ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆ‰∫ßÂìÅÔºå‰ªéËÄå‰øùÈöúÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑ‰∏ÄËá¥ÊÄßÂíåÂèØÈù†ÊÄß„ÄÇ

Âçè‰Ωú‰∏é‰∫íÊìç‰ΩúÊÄß:  

Âú®‰ªªÂä°ÊâßË°å‰∏≠ÔºåAI Âä©ÊâãÂçèË∞É Joule AgentsÔºåÈÄöËøáËßÑÂàíÂíåÊâßË°åÂ§çÊùÇÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÊù•Ëá™Âä®Âåñ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÇÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÂà©Áî®ÂπøÊ≥õÁöÑ Joule ÊäÄËÉΩÂ∫ìÂÆåÊàêÂ§çÊùÇ‰ªªÂä°„ÄÇSAP ÁöÑ Agent-to-AgentÔºàA2AÔºâÂçèËÆÆÂÆûÁé∞‰∫Ü AI Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÈó¥ÁöÑÂÆâÂÖ®Âçè‰ΩúÔºå‰Ωø Joule Agents ËÉΩÂ§ü‰∏éÁ¨¨‰∏âÊñπÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÊó†Áºù‰∫íÂä®„ÄÇ

Ê≤ªÁêÜ‰∏éÊéßÂà∂:

Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìËøêË°åÂú®ÂÆâÂÖ®ÁöÑ‰ºÅ‰∏öÁ∫ßÊ°ÜÊû∂ÂÜÖ„ÄÇSAP Á°Æ‰øùÂèØËß£ÈáäÊÄß‰∏éÈÄèÊòéÂ∫¶Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®Êà∑ËÉΩÁêÜËß£Âíå‰ø°‰ªª AI Âª∫ËÆÆ„ÄÇÂØπ‰∫éÂÖ≥ÈîÆË°åÂä®ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªü‰ºöÈÄöËøá Joule ÂØªÊ±Ç‰∫∫Â∑•ÊâπÂáÜÔºå‰ªéËÄåÂÆûÁé∞Ëá™Âä®Âåñ‰∏éÁõëÁù£‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÂπ≥Ë°°„ÄÇ

             

Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÊûÑÂª∫‰∏éÂºÄÂèëÁÅµÊ¥ªÊÄß

Âú®Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÊó∂‰ª£ÔºåÂºÄÂèëËÄÖËßíËâ≤Ê≠£‰ªé‰ª£Á†ÅÁºñÂÜôËÄÖÊºîÂèò‰∏∫Êô∫ËÉΩ‰∏öÂä°Êû∂ÊûÑÂ∏àÔºåË¶ÅÊ±ÇÊéåÊè°Êô∫ËÉΩÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅËÆæËÆ°Âíå AI ÁõëÁù£ËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇ

SAP ÈÄöËøá SAP Build‚Äã Âíå SAP Build Code‚Äã Èôç‰ΩéÂºÄÂèëÈó®ÊßõÔºåÊîØÊåÅÊÑèÂõæÈ©±Âä®ÂºÄÂèëÔºàVibe CodingÔºâÔºåÂÖÅËÆ∏ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÁî®Ëá™ÁÑ∂ËØ≠Ë®ÄÊèèËø∞ÊÑèÂõæÔºåÁî± AI ÁîüÊàê‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÅÈÄªËæëÂíåÁî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢„ÄÇ

SAP ‰∏∫ÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÊûÑÂª∫ÂíåÂÆöÂà∂Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑÁÅµÊ¥ªÈÄîÂæÑ„ÄÇÂÆ¢Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî® Joule Studio‚Äã Âíå Agent Builder‚Äã Êù•Êâ©Â±ï SAP È¢ÑÂª∫ÁöÑÊô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì„ÄÇËøôÂÖÅËÆ∏ÂÆ¢Êà∑ÂºïÂÖ•Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµ„ÄÅËá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÂíåËá™ÂÆö‰πâÊé®ÁêÜÈÄªËæëÔºåÂêåÊó∂‰øùÁïô SAP Êèê‰æõÁöÑÊ∑±Â±ÇÈõÜÊàêËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇ

Agent Builder ÈÄöËøáËá™ÁÑ∂ËØ≠Ë®ÄÂíåÊãñÊîæÁïåÈù¢ÂºïÂØºÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂÆö‰πâÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑËßíËâ≤„ÄÅÂàÜÈÖç‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÅËøûÊé•Áõ∏ÂÖ≥Êï∞ÊçÆÔºåÂπ∂ÈÖçÂ§áÁõ∏Â∫îÁöÑÊäÄËÉΩÔºàSkillsÔºâ„ÄÇ ÊûÑÂª∫ÂÆöÂà∂Êô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì ÂØπ‰∫éÂÆöÂà∂Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÔºåÂºÄÂèëËÄÖÂèØÈÄâÊã©‰∏§Áßç‰∏ªË¶ÅÊñπÂºèÔºö

  • ‰Ωé‰ª£Á†ÅÔºàLow-CodeÔºâÔºö‰ΩøÁî® Agent Builder Âíå Joule StudioÔºåÈÄöËøáËá™ÁÑ∂ËØ≠Ë®ÄÂíåÊãñÊîæÂäüËÉΩÂÆûÁé∞„ÄÇ
  • ‰∏ì‰∏ö‰ª£Á†ÅÔºàPro-CodeÔºâÔºö‰∏∫ËøΩÊ±ÇÁªàÊûÅÊéßÂà∂ÂíåÁÅµÊ¥ªÊÄßÁöÑ‰∏ì‰∏öÂºÄÂèëËÄÖËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÂÖÅËÆ∏‰ΩøÁî®‰ªª‰ΩïÁºñÁ®ãËØ≠Ë®Ä„ÄÅ‰ªª‰ΩïÈÄªËæëÂíå‰ªª‰ΩïÁé∞ÊúâÁöÑÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÊ°ÜÊû∂ÔºàÂ¶Ç LangGraphÔºå Crew AI Á≠âÔºâÊù•ÊûÑÂª∫Êô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì„ÄÇÊâ©Â±ïÂêéÁöÑ SAP Cloud SDK for AI‚Äã Á°Æ‰øù‰∏é SAP Â∫ïÂ±ÇÂéüÂàôÁöÑÊ∑±Â∫¶ÈõÜÊàê„ÄÇ

 

Êú™Êù•Â±ïÊúõÔºöAI È©±Âä®ÁöÑ‰ºÅ‰∏öËΩ¨Âûã

Joule Agents Á≠ñÁï•Êó®Âú®Âä†ÈÄüËΩ¨ÂûãÔºåÂÖ∂ÊÑøÊôØÊòØ‰Ωø AI Âä©Êâã‰ªéÊèê‰æõÂª∫ËÆÆËøõÂåñÂà∞Âú®‰∫∫Á±ªÁöÑÊåÅÁª≠ÊéßÂà∂‰∏ãËøõË°åÁ´ØÂà∞Á´ØËá™‰∏ªÊâßË°å„ÄÇÈöèÁùÄË∂äÊù•Ë∂äÂ§öÁöÑÈ¢ÑÂª∫Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìË¢´ÂèëÂ∏ÉÔºåÂÆÉ‰ª¨Ê≠£Âú®ÂêÑ‰∏™‰∏öÂä°ÂäüËÉΩ‰∏≠Â∏¶Êù•ÊòæËëóÁöÑÊïàÁéáÊèêÂçá„ÄÇ SAP Ê≠£ÈÄöËøáËøô‰∫õÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÔºåÈ©±Âä®‰ºÅ‰∏ö‰ªé‰∫ãÂä°ÊÄßÂ∑•‰ΩúËΩ¨ÂêëÊàòÁï•ÊÄßÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºåÂÆûÁé∞Êõ¥È´òÁöÑÊïàÁéá„ÄÅÂèØÈù†ÊÄßÔºåÂπ∂ÊîπËøõÂ∑•‰ΩúË¥®ÈáèÂíåËÆæËÆ°„ÄÇ

Âú®Êô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÊó∂‰ª£ÔºåÂºÄÂèëËÄÖ‰∏ç‰ºöÊ∂àÂ§±ÔºåËÄåÊòØÊ≠£Âú®Ë¢´Ë∂ÖÁ∫ßËµãËÉΩÔºàsuperchargedÔºâÔºåÊàê‰∏∫Êô∫ËÉΩ‰∫íËÅî‰∏öÂä°ÁöÑÊû∂ÊûÑÂ∏à„ÄÇ

entry.title: Re: SAC - Update Dimension Values in a Planning Model Wit...
entry.content:
@Wioletta_Sokolowska-Fabisz You can do this directly in the story using Distribute Value. This lets you move the data from the old ProductID to the new ProductID without deleting or reloading anything.

Steps:

  1. Select the cell for the old ProductID (for example, ‚ÄúA‚Äù).

  2. Right-click and choose Distribute Value.

  3. In the panel, select the new ProductID (for example, ‚ÄúABC‚Äù) as the target.

  4. Click Apply.

SAC will then:

  • Create new planning records under ProductID = ‚ÄúABC‚Äù, and

  • Clear the values under the old ProductID

 Example: I want to move the bookings from "Orange no pulp" to "Orange without pulp". Then here is what I would do in the story level. 

1. Have a table that shows my product dimension.

2. Right click on the original product ID which I want to transfer, and select distribute value.

3. In the "Whete to?" section of the planning panel that appears I will use the "Add Target" button to select the target product where I want the values to be transferred. Then select "Equally" as the distribution key. And verify in the live preview of table that the source values are correctly getting transferred to target. Finally click Apply.

entry.title: Re: SAC Story: How to filter a chart on another page base...
entry.content:
Adding to Michael‚Äôs answer Linked Analysis is indeed a good approach.

I would also like to mention another option that can improve the user experience:

Use a Hyperlink with Filters to Jump to the Second Page

You can add a Hyperlink to the pie chart that:

  • Navigates directly to Page 2

  • Automatically applies the selected Material as a filter on that page

This way, when a user clicks a slice of the pie chart, they are taken straight to the monthly view with the correct Material already filtered.

Steps (shown in screenshots):

  1. Right-click the chart ‚Üí More Options ‚Üí Add ‚Üí Hyperlink

  2. Set ‚ÄúLink To‚Äù as Page, and choose Page 2

  3. Enable Apply Selected Dimension as a Filter

  4. (Optional) Enable Cascading Effect if you want other filters to be respected

This provides a smooth drill-down experience between pages where the user would feel like they start at a slice of pie and then navigate to a deeper analysis for that slice of pie. 

Then in view mode: the user can use the "Jump to" option that appears when clicking on slice of pie.

That will take them to the first page with the filters applied.

entry.title: Optimising Sourcing Cycle Times: What‚Äôs Slowing Down Your Sourcing Process?
entry.content:
Let‚Äôs assume you‚Äôve read Part 1 of this series and nodded along thinking, ‚ÄúYep. We‚Äôre not moving fast enough.‚Äù But here‚Äôs the thing, it‚Äôs not about working harder to source faster.  It‚Äôs about removing the friction that slows you down at every step. 

In this second part, we‚Äôre zooming in on what causes delays in your sourcing process, and how to fix them with smarter tools, repeatable methods, and a bit of process discipline.

From Bottlenecks to Business Value

Reducing sourcing cycle time isn‚Äôt about shaving a few hours off a single approval.  It‚Äôs about rethinking the full sourcing journey from end to end, from demand capture all the way to contract creation.  And it‚Äôs about turning every step into a value driver. 

Here‚Äôs the truth: most organizations lose time not because they don‚Äôt have tools, but because those tools aren‚Äôt activated, aligned, or embedded in daily execution.  Below is a framework I use in customer workshops, I call it the Sourcing Value Flow:

Key Features that Actually Deliver Time Savings

  • Enable structured sourcing with milestone-based timelines, task ownership, and SLA tracking
  • Drives 25‚Äì40% faster approvals and increases task completion visibility
  • Modifying a Sourcing Template
  • Project Template Management
  •  

 

 

  • Guided Sourcing AI recommends templates, suppliers, and content based on past events, sourcing patterns, and category context
  • This helps reduce manual setup time and improving event quality from the start
  • Joule in Guided Sourcing
  • Guided Sourcing AI Lab
  • WalkMe in Guided sourcing

 

  • Compress pricing cycles and drive competitive tension through real-time bidding events
  • Reverse Auctions reduce negotiation time by 20‚Äì50% and often improve savings outcomes
  • eAuctions Lab
  • eAuctions Value Accelerator
  • Live eAuctions Demo

 

 

  • Simplify event creation for all user types using intuitive intake, templates, and automated workflows
  • Customers using Guided Sourcing launch 2√ó more events per FTE, with cycle times reduced by 30‚Äì40%.
  • Guided Sourcing Demo
  • Guided Sourcing Lab
  • Guided Sourcing Playbook

 

  • Standardize and reuse event templates, scoring criteria, questions, and documents to reduce setup time
  • Template reuse reduces event creation time by up to 70%
  • Working with Sourcing Library
  • Sourcing Library Demo
  • Loading files to Sourcing Library
  •  

 

  •  Accelerate supplier identification through AI-matched recommendations and supplier filtering tools
  • Events using Discovery receive first bids 2‚Äì3√ó faster, especially in indirect categories
  • Creating a Discovery Posting
  • SAP Discovery Intro
  • RFI's on SAP Business Network

Final Takeaway

Every hour saved is capacity gained. The sourcing teams that win are the ones who standardize, scale, and measure. You don‚Äôt need a moonshot to reduce your cycle time; you just need to activate and adopt what already exists.

Up next? Part 3, ‚ÄúHow‚Äù to do it. The Activation Blueprint. We‚Äôll cover enablement structures, process insights, SAP Joule AI, and real examples of how teams go from ‚Äúgo-live‚Äù to ‚Äúgo faster.‚Äù

entry.title: Tracing Smart Forms and Driver Programs from Output Types in SAP ‚Äì Debugging Made Easy.
entry.content:
Introduction: -- 

Smart Forms are widely used in SAP to generate business outputs like Order Confirmations, Billing Documents, etc. However, identifying which Smart Form and driver program are linked to a particular output type, and how to debug them, is not always straightforward. 

This blog provides a clear and separate step-by-step guide for: -- 

  • Sales Orders (VA03) ‚Äì Application V1 
  • Billing Documents (VF03) ‚Äì Application V3 

We'll cover how to: -

  • Identify the driver program and Smart Form 
  • Trigger and debug the output 
  • Trace the data flow using breakpoints

Section 1: Sales Orders (VA03 ‚Äì Application V1) 

Step 1: Identify Output Type Configuration 

  • Go to T-code NACE 

  • Choose Application: V1 (Sales)

  • Click on Output Types. 

  • Select output type and click "Processing Routines". 

Here You‚Äôll see: --

  • Driver Program  
  • Form Routine 
  • Smart Form name

Then we will go to the driver program and put the debugger point.

Debug via VA03: --

  • Go to VA03, enter a valid sales order.
  • Navigate to Extras ‚Üí Output ‚Üí Header ‚Üí Print Preview.
  • The system triggers the output program, and if you've placed breakpoints in the identified driver program, it enters debugging mode.

Section 2: Billing Documents (VF03 ‚Äì Application V3)

Step 1: Identify Output Type Configuration

  • Go to T-code NACE.
  • Choose Application: V3 (Billing).

  • Click on Output Types.
  • Select output type and click "Processing Routines".

Here You‚Äôll see: --

  • Driver Program
  • Form Routine
  • Smart Form information

Then we will go to the driver program and put the debugger point.

Trigger and Debug Output from VF03: --

  • Access VF03, input the billing document.
  • Navigate to Goto ‚Üí Header ‚Üí Output, select the output type and choose Repeat Output.
  • Use the Further Data option to configure the output's request for reprocessing.
  • To manually trigger debugging: --
  • Use Program RSNAST00
  • Provide relevant document and output type details
  • Execute to simulate output processing and hit breakpoints

Remember: --

Debugging Smart Forms is not just about fixing errors. it's about understanding the full flow from document to output and ensuring quality deliverables to your business users.

Conclusion: --

Understanding how to trace and debug Smart Forms and their associated driver programs is essential for any SAP ABAP developer or functional consultant involved in output management.

By following the structured steps for Sales (VA03 - V1) and Billing (VF03 - V3) provided in this blog, you can:

  • Quickly locate the output type configuration using NACE.
  • Identify the correct driver program and Smart Form.
  • Set effective breakpoints and debug output logic.
  • Use tools like RSNAST00, and SOST for monitoring and troubleshooting.
  • Ensure correct data is passed from application documents to the Smart Form output

Thank You__

entry.title: Re: Add a link to an already posted Supplier Invoice (Cre...
entry.content:
Hello @JAS3311

Good to read it is clearer now and thanks for the follow-up question.

The simple answer to that question is the apps use different technical attachment frameworks. Basically, saying that the link is stored on the MM attachment object and not the FI document. The system allows the links because the app uses the MM Invoice Business Object and this supports Files and URLs. Therefore, adding a link does not violate your audit and legal restrictions which are core to the public clouds clean-core principle.

However, you cannot add links in the FI viewer because the app only allows you to read file attachments.

I hope this clarifies your question.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Use Case for the Special Operation Activity in SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Background

The Special Operation Activities and Special Operation Activity Routings have been available in SAP DM since the early releases with its origin from the legacy SAP Manufacturing Execution (ME) application.  The Special Operation (the term used in ME) was quite popular and used for many years by customers and partners alike.

The initial use case driving the Special Operation development in ME was intended for quality personnel to perform an "out of box" audit of in-process material by randomly "pulling a unit" from the manufacturing line and inspecting or reviewing it in an offline setting. 

Over time, the Special Operation routing was incorporated into the nonconformance process to serve as the offline analysis and repair stations separate from the main production line.

 

Business Context

During production, it is often necessary to divert certain SFCs from their normal routing due to quality issues, engineering changes, or operator observations. Rather than modifying the standard routing for every possible exception, SAP DM allows specific SFCs to be sent to a Special Operation Activity. This creates flexibility while maintaining process control and full visibility of the SFC‚Äôs status.

Typical scenarios include:

  • A product fails an in-process inspection and requires rework or additional testing.
  • Random audits of in-process SFCs.
  • The material requires additional verification steps before returning to the normal flow.

In SAP Digital Manufacturing (SAP DM), a Special Operation Activity/Routing provides a controlled method for removing an SFC from its standard production flow and routing it to a non-standard process such as rework, inspection, or material review. This ensures that all production, quality, and genealogy data remain traceable while allowing operators to execute specialized activities that are not part of the main routing sequence.

 

Configuration

  •  Define a Special Operation Activity type in Manage Operation Activities in SAP DM that is not tied to the main routing.  This will automatically create a Special Operation Activity Routing that is available in the Manage Routings/Recipes application.
  •  With this newly created Special Operation Activity Routing, configure additional Operation Activities as required and the corresponding return paths (dispositions) after completion.
  •  While not required, it is useful to create a dedicated POD for a given special operation activity to isolate quality or rework tasks.
  • Where appropriate for certain business processes, ensure the Operation Activity POD and related Plugins are configured to recognize the special operation activity and supports SFC selection, rework data collection, and NC closure.

Here is an example of a Special Operation Activity Routing called Preliminary Material Review or PMR.

In this example, there a four disposition options:

  1. Return to Any Previous Operation
  2. Send to another Special Operation Activity Routing
  3. Scrap
  4. Done (shown as a Tick Mark and it is the Default disposition)

 

Note:  It is good practice to add the Done step to these types of routings as a reminder that Done is the default disposition when the SFC completes that Special Operation Activity.

Comment:  It is strongly recommended to not add a production routing/recipe as a disposition.

 

Execution Flow

  1. The SFC is identified as requiring rework or special processing.
  2. An SFC can be sent to a Special Operation Activity by logging a nonconformance that has the SOA routing assigned, or an SFC can be 'pulled' into a Special Operation Activity manually when required.
  3. The SFC‚Äôs status is updates to indicate it is on the special operation activity routing.
  4. Operators perform the necessary tasks in the Special Operation Activity POD.
  5. Upon completion, the SFC is dispositioned back to the main routing or another appropriate disposition function (such as scrap, Done, or another routing), ensuring full traceability.

As with any new configuration and business process, please thoroughly define, model and test various use cases (including corner cases) in a testing environment prior to implementing in a productive environment. 

 

Triggering the Transfer of the SFC into a Special Operation Activity

Generally, an SFC can be sent to a Special Operation Activity by logging a nonconformance that has the Special Operation Activity routing assigned, or an SFC can be "pulled" into a Special Operation Activity (operator-initiated pull into the Special Operation Activity routing).

There are multiple ways an SFC can be directed to a Special Operation Activity:

  • Manual Operator Action: At a Work Center or Operation POD, an operator can use a custom button or action (e.g., 'Send to Rework') that sends the SFC to a disposition routing. This allows quick redirection without exiting the production context.
  • Automated Quality Integration: Integration with Nonconformance (NC) processes (tests or inspections) can automatically send an SFC to a Special Operation Activity when a NC is recorded by an operator in the POD or an NC code is raised via the APIs.
  • The SFC can be "pulled" into the Special Operation Activity by specifying the SFC value and performing the Start action.  The SFC will be moved from its current location (usually on a production routing) to the Special Operation Activity.

 

Scenario 1:  Here is an example where an SFC was sent into the Special Operation Activity by logging a nonconformance that had the Special Operation Activity Routing assigned to it as a disposition option.

Below is the SFC Report showing the progression of activities as the SFC was sent from the main routing to the Special Operation Activity and subsequently returned back to the main routing.

 

Scenario 2:  Here is an example where an SFC was "pulled" into the Special Operation Activity by entering the SFC in the SFC Field of this Operation Activity POD and selecting the Start action.

 

Triggering the Exit of the SFC out of the Special Operation Activity

When the SFC completes the Special Operation Activity, the dispositions options defined in the Special Operation Activity routing will be displayed to the user.  Here are the four options previously configured and the user can select one for the next step in the process for the SFC (including Done).  The SFC will them leave the Special Operation Activity and be placed according to the selected disposition.

 

Future Enhancements

There are future enhancements planned (subject to change) for the Special Operation Activity including providing the ability to collect and report time (activities) while the SFC is on the Special Operation Activity Routing and supporting the "Change Production" use case so that if an SFC is on the Special Operation Activity Routing and a production change is incorporated, the SFC can be placed on the updated routing accordingly.

 

Benefits

  • Allows for flexibility in how an SFC is processed offline from the primary production flow.
  • Enables controlled deviation from standard production routing.
  • Provides the ability to "pull" SFCs from the production routing without having to log a nonconformance. 
  • Supports both manual and automated rework or "random audit" flows.
  • Simplifies operator experience by providing clear visual workflows for rework or inspection.

 

Conclusion

The Special Operation Activity is a useful way to temporarily move an SFC from the main routing to an offline area for nonconformance or audit purposes while allowing a means to appropriately disposition the SFC upon completion of those offline processes.
